lines.value:
Helen
By Euripides
Written 412 B.C.E
Translated by E. P. Coleridge

Lo! These are the fair virgin streams of Nile, the river that 
waters Egypt's tilth, fed by pure melting snow instead of rain from heaven. 
Proteus during his life-time was king of this land, dwelling in the isle 
of Pharos, and ruling o'er Egypt; and he took to wife one of the daughters 
of the sea, Psamathe, after she left the embraces of Aeacus. Two children 
she bare in this his palace, a son Theoclymenus, who hath passed his life 
in duteous service to the gods, and likewise a noble daughter, her mother's 
pride, called Eido in her infancy, but when she reached her youthful prime, 
the age for wedded joys, renamed Theonoe; for well she knew whate'er the 
gods design, both present and to come, for she had won this guerdon from 
her grandsire Nereus. Nor is my fatherland unknown to fame, e'en Sparta, 
or my sire Tyndareus; for a legend tells how Zeus winged his way to my 
mother Leda's breast, in the semblance of a bird, even a swan, and thus 
as he fled from an eagle's pursuit, achieved by guile his amorous purpose, 
if this tale be true. My name is Helen, and I will now recount the sorrows 
I have suffered. To a hollow vale on Ida came three goddesses to Paris, 
for beauty's prize contending, Hera and Cypris, and the virgin child of 
Zeus, eager to secure his verdict on their loveliness. Now Cypris held 
out my beauty,-if aught so wretched deserves that name,-as a bride before 
the eyes of Paris, saying he should marry me; and so she won the day; wherefore 
the shepherd of Ida left his steading, and came to Sparta, thinking to 
win me for his bride. But Hera, indignant at not defeating the goddesses, 
brought to naught my marriage with Paris, and gave to Priam's princely 
son not Helen, but a phantom endowed with life, that she made in my image 
out of the breath of heaven; and Paris thought that I was his, although 
I never was,-an idle fancy! Moreover, the counsels of Zeus added further 
troubles unto these; for upon the land of Hellas and the hapless Phrygians 
he brought a war, that he might lighten mother-earth of her myriad hosts 
of men, and to the bravest of the sons of Hellas bring renown. So I was 
set up as a prize for all the chivalry of Hellas, to test the might of 
Phrygia, yet not I, but my name alone; for Hermes caught me up in the embracing 
air, and veiled me in a cloud; for Zeus was not unmindful of me; and he 
set me down here in the house of Proteus, judging him to be the most virtuous 
of all mankind; that so I might preserve my marriage with Menelaus free 
from taint. Here then I abide, while my hapless lord has gathered an army, 
and is setting out for the towers of Ilium to track and recover me. And 
there by Scamander's streams hath many a life breathed out its last, and 
all for me; and I, that have endured all this, am accursed, and seem to 
have embroiled all Hellas in a mighty war by proving a traitress to my 
husband. Why, then, do I prolong my life? Because I heard Hermes declare, 
that I should yet again make my home on Sparta's glorious soil, with my 
lord,-for Hermes knew I never went to Ilium,-that so I might never submit 
to any other's wooing. Now as long as Proteus gazed upon yon glorious sun, 
I was safe from marriage; but when o'er him the dark grave closed, the 
dead man's son was eager for my hand. But I, from regard to my former husband, 
am throwing myself down in suppliant wise before this tomb of Proteus, 
praying him to guard my husband's honour, that, though through Hellas I 
bear a name dishonoured, at least my body here may not incur disgrace.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Who is lord and master of this fenced palace? The house is 
one I may compare to the halls of Plutus, with its royal bulwarks and towering 
buildings. Ha! great gods! what sight is here? I see the counterfeit of 
that fell murderous dame, who ruined me and all the Achaeans. May Heaven 
show its loathing for thee, so much dost thou resemble Helen! Were I not 
standing on a foreign soil, with this well-aimed shaft had worked thy death, 
thy reward for resembling the daughter of Zeus.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
Oh! why, poor man, whoe'er thou art, dost thou turn from me, 
loathing me for those troubles Helen caused?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
I was wrong; I yielded to my anger more than I ought; my reason 
was, the hate all Hellas bears to that daughter of Zeus. Pardon me, lady, 
for the words I uttered.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Who art thou? whence comest thou to visit this land?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: One of those hapless Achaeans am I, lady.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
No wonder then that thou dost bate Helen. But say, who art 
thou? Whence comest? By what name am I to call thee?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
My name is Teucer; my sire was Telamon, and Salamis is the 
land that nurtured me.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Then why art thou visiting these meadows by the Nile?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: A wanderer I, an exile from my native land.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
Thine must be a piteous lot; who from thy country drives thee 
out?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: My father Telamon. Couldst find a nearer and a dearer?
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: But why? This case is surely fraught with woe.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: The death of Ajax my brother at Troy was my ruin.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: How so? surely 'twas not thy sword that stole his life away?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: He threw himself on his own blade and died.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
Was he mad? for who with sense endowed would bring himself 
to this?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Dost thou know aught of Achilles. son of Peleus?
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: He came, so I have heard, to woo Helen once.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: When he died, he left his arms for his comrades to contest.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Well, if he did, what harm herein to Ajax?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: When another won these arms, to himself he put an end.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Art thou then a sufferer by woes that he inflicted?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Yes, because I did not join him in his death.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: So thou camest, sir stranger, to Ilium's famous town?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Aye, and, after helping to sack it, myself did learn what ruin 
meant.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Is Troy already fired and utterly by flames consumed?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Yea, so that not so much as one vestige of her walls is now 
to be seen.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Woe is thee, poor Helen! thou art the cause of Phrygia's ruin.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: And of Achaea's too. Ah! 'tis a tale of grievous misery!
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: How long is it since the city was sacked?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Nigh seven fruitful seasons have come and gone.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: And how much longer did ye abide in Troy?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Many a weary month, till through ten full years the moon had 
held her course.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: And did ye capture that Spartan dame?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Menelaus caught her by the hair, and was for dragging her away.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
Didst thou thyself behold that unhappy one? or art thou speaking 
from hearsay?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: As plain as I now see thee, I then saw her.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
Consider whether ye were but indulging an idle fancy sent by 
heaven.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Bethink thee of some other topic; no more of her!
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Are you so sure this fancy was reliable?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
With these eyes I saw her face to face, if so be I see thee 
now.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Hath Menelaus reached his home by this time with his wife?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: No; he is neither in Argos, nor yet by the streams of Eurotas.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
Ah me! here is evil news for those to whom thou art telling 
it.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: 'Tis said he disappeared with his wife.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Did not all the Argives make the passage together?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Yes: but a tempest scattered them in every direction.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: In what quarter of the broad ocean?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: They were crossing the Aegean in mid channel.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: And after that, doth no man know of Menelaus' arrival?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: No; none; but through Hellas is he reported to be dead.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Then am I lost. Is the daughter of Thestius alive?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Dost speak of Leda? She is dead; aye, dead and gone.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Was it Helen's shame that caused her death?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Aye, 'tis said she tied the noose about her noble neck.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Are the sons of Tyndareus still alive or not?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Dead, and yet alive: 'tis a double story.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: Which is the more credible report? Woe is me for my sorrows!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Men say that they are gods in the likeness of stars.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value: That is happy news; but what is the other rumour?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
That they by self-inflicted wounds gave up the ghost because 
of their sister's shame. But enough of such talk! I have no wish to multiply 
my griefs. The reason of my coming to this royal palace was a wish to see 
that famous prophetess Theonoe. Do thou the means afford, that I from her 
may obtain an oracle how I shall steer a favourable course to the sea-girt 
shores of Cyprus; for there Apollo hath declared my home shall be, giving 
to it the name of Salamis, my island home, in honour of that fatherland 
across the main.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
That shall the voyage itself explain, sir stranger; but do 
thou leave these shores and fly, ere the son of Proteus, the ruler of this 
land, catch sight of thee. Now is he away with his trusty hounds tracking 
his savage quarry to the death; for every stranger that he catcheth from 
the land of Hellas doth he slay. His reason never ask to know; my lips 
are sealed; for what could word of mine avail thee?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Lady, thy words are fair. Heaven grant thee a fair requital 
for this kindness! For though in form thou dost resemble Helen, thy soul 
is not like hers, nay, very different. Perdition seize her! May she never 
reach the streams of Eurotas! But thine be joy for evermore, lady!
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
TEUCER departs. The CHORUS OF CAPTIVE GREEK WOMEN enter. They sing responsively 
with HELEN.
lines.speaker: TEUCER

lines.value:
Ah me! what piteous dirge shall I strive to utter, now that 
I am beginning my strain of bitter lamentation? What Muse shall I approach 
with tears or songs of death or woe? Ah me! ye Sirens, Earth's virgin daughters, 
winged maids, come, oh! come to aid my mourning, bringing with you the 
Libyan flute or pipe, to waft to Persephone's ear a tearful plaint, the 
echo of my sorrow, with grief for grief, and mournful chant for chant, 
with songs of death and doom to match my lamentation, that in return she 
may receive from me, besides my tears, dirges for the departed dead beneath 
her gloomy roof!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Beside the deep-blue water I chanced to be hanging purple robes 
along the tendrils green and on the sprouting reeds, to dry them in the 
sun-god's golden blaze, when lo! I heard a sound of woe, a mournful wail, 
the voice of one crying aloud in her anguish; yea, such a cry of woe as 
Naiad nymph might send ringing o'er the hills, while to her cry the depths 
of rocky grots re-echo her screams at the violence of Pan.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Woe! woe! ye maids of Hellas, booty of barbarian sailors! one 
hath come, an Achaean mariner, bringing fresh tears to me, the news of 
Ilium's overthrow, how that it is left to the mercy of the foeman's flame, 
and all for me the murderess, or for my name with sorrow fraught. While 
for anguish at my deed of shame, hath Leda sought her death by hanging; 
and on the deep, to weary wandering doomed my lord hath met his end; and 
Castor and his brother, twin glory of their native land, are vanished from 
men's sight, leaving the plains that shook to their galloping steeds, and 
the course beside reed-fringed Eurotas, where those youthful athletes strove.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Ah, misery! Alas! for thy grievous destiny! Woe for thy sad 
lot, lady! Ah! 'twas a day of sorrow meted out for thee when Zeus came 
glancing through the sky on snowy pinions like a swan and won thy mother's 
heart. What evil is not thine? Is there a grief in life that thou hast 
not endured? Thy mother is dead; the two dear sons of Zeus have perished 
miserably, and thou art severed from thy country's sight, while through 
the towns of men a rumour runs, consigning thee, my honoured mistress, 
to a barbarian's bed; and 'mid the ocean waves thy lord hath lost his life, 
and never, never more shalt thou fill with joy thy father's halls or Athena's 
temple of the "Brazen House."
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Ah! who was that Phrygian, who was he, that felled that pine 
with sorrow fraught for Ilium, and for those that came from Hellas? Hence 
it was that Priam's son his cursed barque did build, and sped by barbarian 
oars sailed unto my home, in quest of beauty, woman's curse, to win me 
for his bride; and with him sailed the treacherous queen of Love, on slaughter 
bent, with death alike for Priam's sons, and Danai too. Ah me! for my hard 
lot! Next, Hera, stately bride of Zeus, seated on her golden throne, sent 
the son of Maia, swift of foot, who caught me up as I was gathering fresh 
rose-buds in the folds of my robe, that I might go to the "Brazen House," 
and bore me through the air to this loveless land, making me an object 
of unhappy strife 'twixt Hellas and the race of Priam. And my name is but 
a sound without reality beside the streams of Simois.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Well I know thou hast a bitter lot to bear; still 'tis best 
to bear as lightly as we may the ills that life is heir to.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
Good friends, to what a fate am I united? Did not my mother 
bear me to be a monster to the world? For no woman, Hellene or barbarian, 
gives birth to babes in eggs inclosed, as they say Leda bare me to Zeus. 
My life and all I do is one miracle, partly owing to Hera, and partly is 
my beauty to blame. Would God I could rub my beauty out like a picture, 
and assume hereafter in its stead a form less comely, and oh! that Hellas 
had forgotten the evil fate that now I bear, and were now remembering my 
career of honour as surely as they do my deeds of shame. Now, if a man 
doth turn his eyes to a single phase of fortune, and meets ill-usage at 
heaven's hands, 'tis hard no doubt; but still it can be borne; but I in 
countless troubles am involved. First, although I never sinned, my good 
name is gone. And this is a grief beyond the reality, if a man incurs blame 
for sins that are not his. Next, have the gods removed me from my native 
land, to dwell with men of barbarous ways, and reft of every friend, I 
arn become a slave though free by birth; for amongst barbarians all are 
slaves but one. And the last anchor that held my fortunes, the hope that 
my husband would return one day, and rid me of my woes, is now no more, 
lost since the day he died. My mother too is dead, and I am called her 
murderess, unjustly it is true, but still that injustice is mine to bear; 
and she that was the glory of my house, my darling child, is growing old 
and grey, unwedded still; and those twin brethren, called the sons of Zeus, 
are now no more. But 'tis fortune, not my own doing, that hath crushed 
me with sorrow and slain me. And this is the last evil of all; if ever 
I come to my native land. they will shut me up in prison, thinking me that 
Helen of Ilium, in quest of whom Menelaus came thither. Were my husband 
still alive, we might have recognized each other, by having recourse to 
tokens which ourselves alone would know. But now this may not be, nor is 
there any chance of his escape. Why then do I prolong my life? What fortune 
have I still in store? Shall I choose marriage as an alternative of evils, 
and dwell with a barbarian lord, seated at his sumptuous board? No! when 
a husband she loathes is mated with a woman, even life is loathly to her. 
Best for her to die; but how shall I die a noble death? The dangling noose 
is an uncomely end; even slaves consider it disgrace; to stab oneself hath 
something fair and. noble in it; 'tis a small thing that moment of ridding 
the flesh of life. Yes, it must be; I am plunged so deep in misery; for 
that beauty, which to other women is a boon, to me hath been a very bane.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Helen, never believe that the stranger, whoe'er he was that 
came, has spoken naught but truth.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: Yet he said so clearly that my lord was dead.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: There is much that falsehood seems to make quite clear.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: The word of truth hath a very different sound to falsehood.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Thou art inclined to misfortune, rather than to luck.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Fear girds me with terrors as with a garment, and takes me 
in her train.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: What friends hast thou within the palace?
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: All are my friends here save him who seeks to wed-me.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Thy action then is clear; leave thy seat at the tomb.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value: To what words or advice art thou leading up?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Go in and question the daughter of the ocean Nereid, who knoweth 
all things, even Theonoe, whether thy husband is still alive, or whether 
he hath left the light of day; and when thou knowest for certain, be glad 
or sorrowful, as fits thy fortune. But before thou hast right knowledge, 
what shall sorrow avail thee? Nay, hearken to me; leave this tomb and seek 
the maiden's company, that she may tell thee the truth, for from her shalt 
thou learn all. If thou abide here in this seat, what prospect hast thou? 
And I will myself go in with thee, and with thee inquire of the maiden's 
oracles; for 'tis a woman's bounden duty to share a sister's trouble.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
The following lines are chanted responsively by HELEN and the 
CHORUS.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Kind friends, I welcome your advice. Come in, come in, that 
ye may learn the result of my struggle within the palace.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Thy invitation comes to very willing ears.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Woe for this heavy day! Ah me! what mournful tidings shall 
hear?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Dear mistress mine, be not a prophetess of sorrow, forestalling 
lamentation.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
What is the fate of my poor husband? Doth he still behold the 
light turning towards the sun-god's chariot and the stars in their courses? 
Or among the dead, beneath the earth, is he to death consigned?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Of the future take a brighter view, whatever shall betide.
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
On thee I call, and thee adjure, Eurotas green with river-reeds, 
to tell me if this rumour of my husband's death be true.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
About my neck will I fasten the deadly noose from above, or 
drive the murderous knife with self-aimed thrust deep into my throat to 
sever it, striving to cut my flesh, a sacrifice to those goddesses three 
and to that son of Priam, who in days gone by would wake the music of his 
pipe around his steading.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Oh may sorrow be averted otherwhither, and thou be blest!
lines.speaker: CHORUS

lines.value:
Woe is thee, unhappy Troy! Thou through deeds not done by the 
art ruined, and hast suffered direst woe; for the gift that Cypris gave 
to me, hath caused a sea of blood to flow, and many an eye to weep, with 
grief on grief and tear on tear. All this hath Ilium suffered and mothers 
have lost their children; and virgin sisters of the slain have cut off 
their tresses by the swollen tide of Phrygian Scamander. And the land of 
Hellas hath lifted her voice of woe and broken forth in wailing, smiting 
on her head, and making tender cheeks to stream with gore beneath the rending 
nail. Ah blest maid Callisto, who long ago in Arcady didst find favour 
with Zeus, in the semblance of beast four-footed, how much happier was 
thy lot than my mother's, for thou hast changed the burden of thy grief 
and now with savage eye art weeping o'er thy shaggy monster-shape; aye, 
and hers was a happier lot, whom on a day Artemis drove from her choir, 
changed to a hind with horns of gold, the fair Titanian maid, daughter 
of Merops, because of her beauty; but my fair form hath proved the curse 
of Dardan Troy and doomed Achaea's sons.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
HELEN and the CHORUS go into the palace. After the doors have closed 
upon them, MENELAUS enters. He is alone and clad in 
rags.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Ah! Pelops, easy victor long ago o'er thy rival Oenomaus in 
the chariot-race on Pisa's plain, would thou hadst ended thy career amongst 
the gods that day thou wert beguiled into making a banquet for them, or 
ever thou hadst begotten my father Atreus, to whom were born by Aerope 
his wife, Agamemnon and myself Menelaus, an illustrious pair; and herein 
I make no idle boast, for 'twas a mighty host, I trow, that I their leader 
carried o'er the sea to Troy, using no violence to make them follow me, 
but leading all the chivalry of Hellas by voluntary consent. And some of 
these must we number 'mid the slain, and some to their joy have 'scaped 
the sea, bearing to their homes again names long reckoned dead. But I, 
poor wretch, go wandering o'er grey Ocean's swell a weary space, long as 
that which saw me sick the towers of Ilium; and for all my longing to reach 
my country I am not counted worthy of this boon by heaven, but to Libya's 
desert cheerless roadsteads have I sailed, to each and all of them; and 
whensoe'er I draw me near my native land, the storm-wind drives me back 
again, and never yet have favouring breezes filled my sails, to let me 
reach my fatherland. And now a wretched, shipwrecked mariner, my friends 
all lost, am I cast up upon this shore; and my ship is shattered in a thousand 
pieces against the rocks; and its keel was wrested from its cunning fastenings; 
thereon did I with difficulty escape, most unexpectedly, and Helen also, 
for her had I rescued from Troy and had with me. But the name of this country 
and its people I know not; for I blushed to mingle with the crowd to question 
them, anxious for very shame to hide my misfortunes which reduce me to 
these sorry rags. For when a man of high degree meets with adversity, he 
feels the strangeness of his fallen state more keenly than a sufferer of 
long standing. Dire want is wasting me; for I have neither food, nor raiment 
to gird myself withal; behold the facts before you to judge from-I am clad 
in tatters cast up from the ship; while all the robes I once did wear, 
glorious attire and ornaments, bath the sea swallowed; and in a cavern's 
deep recesses have I hidden my wife, the cause of all my trouble, and have 
come hither, after straitly charging the survivors of my friends to watch 
her. Alone am I come, seeking for those there left some help, if haply 
I may find it after careful search. So when I saw this palace girt with 
towering walls and stately gates of some prosperous lord, I drew nigh; 
for I have hope to obtain somewhat for my sailors from this wealthy house, 
whereas from houses which have no store, the inmates for all their goodwill 
could furnish naught. Ho! there, who keeps the gate and will come forth 
to bear my tale of woe into the house?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
A PORTRESS comes out of the palace in answer to his 
call.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Who stands before the door? Begone from the housel stand not 
at the court-yard gate, annoying my masters! otherwise shalt thou die, 
for thou art a Hellene born. and with them have we no dealings.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value:
Mother, herein sayest thou rightly on all points. 'Tis well; 
I will obey; but moderate thy words.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Away! stranger, my orders are to admit no Hellene to this palace.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: Ha! do not seek to push me hence, or thrust me away by violence.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Thou dost not heed my words, and therefore hast thyself to 
blame.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: Carry my message to thy master in the palace.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Some one would rue it, methinks, were I to take thy message.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: I come as a shipwrecked man and a stranger, whom heaven protects.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Well, get thee to some other house than this.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: Nay, but I will pass into the house; so listen to me.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Let me tell thee thou art unwelcome, and soon wilt be forcibly 
ejected.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: Ah me! where are now those famous troops of mine?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Elsewhere maybe thou wert a mighty man; thou art not here.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: O fortune! I have not deserved such insult.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Why are thy eyes with tear-drops wet? Why so sad?
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: 'Tis the contrast with my fortunes erst so blest.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Hence! then, and give thy friends those tears.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: What land is this? whose is the palace?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Proteus lives here. It is the land of Egypt.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: Egypt? Woe is me! to think that hither I have sailed!
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Pray, what fault hast thou to find with the race of Nile?
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: 'Twas no fault I found; my own disasters I lament.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: There be plenty in evil case; thou art not the only one.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: Is the king, of whom thou speakest, here within?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: There is his tomb; his son rules in his stead.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: And where may he be? abroad, or in the house?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: He is not within. To Hellas is he a bitter foe.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value:
His reason, pray, for this enmity? the results whereof I have 
experienced.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Beneath this roof dwells the daughter of Zeus, Helen.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value:
What mean'st thou? what is it thou hast said? Repeat, I pray, 
thy words.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: The daughter of Tyndareus is here, who erst in Sparta dwelt.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: Whence came she? What means this business?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: When? Surely I have never been robbed of my wife from the cave!
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Before the Achaeans went to Troy, sir stranger. But get thee 
hence; for somewhat hath chanced within, whereat the whole palace is in 
an uproar. Thou comest most unseasonably; and if my master catch thee, 
death will be thy stranger's gift. This say I, because to Hellas I am well 
disposed, albeit I gave thee harsh answers for fear of my master.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value: The PORTRESS goes back into the palace.
lines.speaker: PORTRESS

lines.value:
What can I think or say? For after my previous troubles, this 
is a fresh piece of ill-luck I hear, if, indeed, after recovering my wife 
from Troy and bringing her hither, and putting her for safety in the cave, 
I am then to find another woman living here with the same name as my wife. 
She called her the begotten child of Zeus. Can there be a man that hath 
the name of Zeus by the banks of Nile? The Zeus of heaven is only one, 
at any rate. Where is there a Sparta in the world save where Eurotas glides 
between his reedy banks? The name of Tyndareus is the name of one alone. 
Is there any land of the same name as Lacedaemon or Troy? I know not what 
to say; for naturally there are many in the wide world that have the same 
names, cities and women too; there is nothing, then, to marvel at. Nor 
yet again will I fly from the alarm a servant raises; for there is none 
so cruel of heart as to refuse me food when once he hears my name. All 
have heard of Ilium's burning, and I, that set it ablaze, am famous now 
throughout the world, I, Menelaus. I therefore wait the master of this 
house. There are two issues I must watch; if he prove somewhat stern of 
heart, I will to my wreck and there conceal myself; but if he show any 
sign of pity, I will ask for help in this my present strait. This is the 
crowning woe in all my misery, to beg the means of life from other princes, 
prince though I be myself; still needs must I. Yea, this is no saying of 
mine, but a word of wisdom, "Naught in might exceedeth dread necessity."
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
HELEN and the CHORUS enter from the palace. They do not notice 
MENELAUS.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Lo! once again I seek the shelter of this tomb, with Theonoe's 
sweet tidings in my ears; she that knoweth all things of a truth; for she 
saith my lord is yet alive and in the light of day, albeit he is roaming 
to and fro after many a weary voyage, and hither shall he come whenso he 
reach the limit of his toils, no novice in the wanderer's life. But one 
thing did she leave unsaid. Is he to escape when he hath come? And I refrained 
from asking that question clearly, so glad was I when she told me he was 
safe. For she said that he was somewhere nigh this shore, cast up by shipwreck 
with a handful of friends. Ah! when shall I see thee come? How welcome 
will thy advent be!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Ho there! thou that with fearful effort seekest to reach the 
basement of the tomb and the pillars of burnt sacrifice, stay thee. Wherefore 
art flying? Ah! with what speechless amaze the sight of thee affects me!
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
O friends! I am being ill-treated. This man is keeping me from 
the tomb, and is eager to take and give me to his master, whose wooing 
I was seeking to avoid.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: No robber I, or minister of evil.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: At any rate the garb wherein thou art clad is unseemly.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Stay thy hasty flight; put fear aside.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: I do so, now that I have reached this spot.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Who art thou? whom do I behold in thee, lady?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Nay, who art thou? The self-same reason prompts us both.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Great God! Yea, for to recognize our friends is of God.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Art thou from Hellas, or a native of this land?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: From Hellas; but I would learn thy story too.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Lady, in thee I see a wondrous likeness to Helen.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: And I in thee to Menelaus; I know not what to say.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Well, thou hast recognized aright a man of many sorrows.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Hail! to thy wife's arms restored at last!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Wife indeed! Lay not a finger on my robe.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: The wife that Tyndareus, my father, gave thee.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: O Hecate, giver of light, send thy visions favourably!
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
In me thou beholdest no spectre of the night, attendant on 
the queen of phantoms.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Nor yet am I in my single person the husband of two wives.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: What other woman calls thee lord?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: The inmate of yonder cave, whom I from Troy convey.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Thou hast none other wife but me.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Can it be my mind is wandering, my sight failing?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Dost not believe thou seest in me thy wife?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Thy form resembles her, but the real truth robs me of this 
belief.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Observe me well; what need hast thou of clearer proof?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Thou art like her; that will I never deny.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Who then shall teach thee, unless it be thine own eyes?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Herein is my dilemma; I have another wife.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: To Troy I never went; that was a phantom.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: The air, whence thou hast a wife of heaven's workmanship.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: What god's handiwork? Strange is the tale thou tellest.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Hera made it as a substitute, to keep me from Paris.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
How then couldst thou have been here, and in Troy, at the same 
time?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: The name may be in many a place at once, though not the body.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Unhand me! the sorrows I brought with me suffice.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: What! wilt leave me, and take that phantom bride away?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: For thy likeness unto Helen, fare thee well.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Ruined! in thee I found my lord only to lose thee.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
The greatness of my troubles at Troy convinces me; thou dost 
not.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Ah, woe is me! who was ever more unfortunate than I? Those 
whom I love best are leaving me, nor shall I ever reach Hellas, my own 
dear native land.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: The FIRST MESSENGER enters in haste.
lines.speaker: HELEN
MESSENGER

lines.value: What news? surely you are not being spoiled by the barbarians?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: A miracle hath happened; my words are too weak for the reality.
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value: Speak; for judging by this haste, thou hast stirring news.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
My message is: thy countless toils have all been toiled in 
vain.
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value: That is an old tale of woe to mourn! come, thy news?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Thy wife hath disappeared, soaring away into the embracing 
air; in heaven she now is hidden, and as she left the hollowed cave where 
we were guarding her, she hailed us thus, "Ye hapless Phrygians, and all 
Achaea's race! for me upon Scamander's strand by Hera's arts ye died from 
day to day, in the false belief that Helen was in the hands of Paris. But 
I, since I have stayed my appointed time, and kept the laws of fate, will 
now depart unto the sky that gave me birth; but the unhappy daughter of 
Tyndareus, through no fault of hers, hath borne an evil name without reason."
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value:
This is even what she said; her words are proved true; O longed-for 
day, how hath it restored thee to my arms!
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
O Menelaus, dearest husband, the time of sorrow has been long, 
but joy is now ours at last. Ah, friends, what joy for me to hold my husband 
in a fond embrace after many a weary cycle of yon blazing lamp of day!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
What joy for me to hold my wife! but with all that I would 
ask about these years, I now know not where I may first begin.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
O rapture! the very hair upon my head starts up for joy! my 
tears run down! Around thy neck I fling my arms, dear husband, to hug my 
joy to me.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
O happy, happy sight! I have no fault to find; my wife, he 
daughter of Zeus and Leda, is mine again, she whom her brothers on their 
snow-white steeds, whilst torches blazed, made my happy bride, but gods 
removed her from my home. Now is the deity guiding us to a new destiny, 
happier than of yore.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Evil into good transformed hath brought us twain together at 
last, dear husband; but late though it be, God grant me joy of my good 
luck!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
God grant thee joy! I join thee in the self-same prayer; for 
of us twain one cannot suffer without the other.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
No more, my friends, I mourn the past; no longer now I grieve. 
My own dear husband is restored to me, whose coming from Troy I have waited 
many a long year.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
I to thee, and thou to me. And after these long, long years 
I have at last discovered the fraud of the goddess. But these tears, in 
gladness shed, are tears of thankfulness rather than of sorrow.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
What can I say? What mortal heart could e'er have had such 
hope? To my bosom I press thee, little as I ever thought to.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
And I to mine press thee, who all men thought hadst gone to 
Ida's town and the hapless towers of Ilium.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Ah me! ah me! that is a bitter subject to begin on.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Tell me, I adjure thee, how wert thou from my home conveyed?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Alas! alas! 'tis a bitter tale thou askest to hear.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Speak, for I must hear it; all that comes is Heaven's gift.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: I loathe the story I am now to tell.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Tell it for all that. 'Tis sweet to hear of trouble past.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
I ne'er set forth to be the young barbarian's bride, with oars 
and wings of lawless love to speed me on my way.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: What deity or fate tore thee from thy country, then?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Ah, my lord! 'twas Hermes, the son of Zeus, that brought and 
placed me by the banks of Nile.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: A miracle! Who sent thee thither? O monstrous story!
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
I wept, and still my eyes are wet with tears. 'Twas the wife 
of Zeus that ruined me.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Hera? wherefore should she afflict us twain?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Woe is me for my awful fate! Woe for those founts and baths 
where the goddesses made brighter still that beauty, which evoked the fatal 
verdict!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Why did Hera visit thee with evil regarding this verdict?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: To wrest the promise of Cypris-
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: From Paris, to whom that goddess pledged me.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: And so she brought me hither to Egypt to my sorrow.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Then she gave him a phantom in thy stead, as thou tellest me?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: And then began those woes of thine, ah, mother! woe is me!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
My mother is no more; my shameful marriage made her fix the 
noose about her neck.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Ah me! is our daughter Hermione yet alive?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Still unwed, childless still, she mourns my fatal marriage.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
O Paris, who didst utterly o'erthrow my home, here was thy 
ruin too and theirs, those countless mail-clad Danai.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
From my country, city, and from thee heaven cast me forth unhappy 
and accursed, because I left,-and yet not I,-home and husband for union 
of foul shame.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
If haply ye find happiness in the future, it will suffice when 
to the past ye look.
lines.speaker: LEADER OF THE CHORUS

lines.value:
Menelaus, grant me too a portion of that joy which, though 
mine own eyes see, I scarcely comprehend.
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value: Come then, old friend, and share with us our talk.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Was it not then in her power to decide all the trouble in Troy?
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value:
It was not; I was tricked by the gods into taking to my arms 
a misty phantom-form, to my sorrow.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: How so? was it then for this we vainly toiled?
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value: 'Twas Hera's handiwork, and the jealousy of three goddesses.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Is this real woman, then, thy wife?
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value: This is she; trust my word for that.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Daughter, how changeful and inscrutable is the nature of God! 
With some good end doth he vary men's fortune-now up, now down; one suffers; 
another who ne'er knew suffering, is in his turn to awful ruin brought, 
having no assurance in his lot from day to day. Thou and thy husband have 
had your share of trouble-thou in what the world has said, he in battle's 
heat. For all the striving that he strove, he got him naught; while now, 
without an effort made, every blessing fortune boasts is his. And thou, 
in spite of all, hast brought no shame upon thy aged sire, or those twin 
sons of Zeus, nor art thou guilty of those rumoured crimes. Now again do 
I recall thy wedding rites, remembering the blazing torch I bore beside 
thee in a four-horsed chariot at full gallop; while thou with this thy 
lord, a new-made bride, wert driving forth from thy happy home. A sorry 
servant he, whoso regardeth not his master's interest, sympathizing with 
his sorrows and his joys. Slave though I was born, yet may I be numbered 
amongst honest servants; for in heart, though not in name, I am free. For 
this is better far than in my single person to suffer these two evils, 
to feel my heart corrupt, and as the slave of others to be at my neighbour's 
beck and call.
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value:
Come, old friend, oft hast thou stood side by side with me 
and taken thy full share of toil; so now be partner in my happiness. Go, 
tell my comrades, whom I left behind, the state of matters here, as thou 
hast found them, and the issue of my fortunes; and bid them wait upon the 
beach and abide the result of the struggle, which I trow awaits me; and 
if mayhap we find a way to take this lady from the land by stealth, tell 
them to keep good watch that we may share the luck and escape, if possible, 
from the barbarian's clutch.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
It shall be done, O king. Now I see how worthless are the seers' 
tricks, how full of falsehood; nor is there after all aught trustworthy 
in the blaze of sacrifice or in the cry of feathered fowls; 'tis folly, 
the very notion that birds can help mankind. Calchas never by word or sign 
showed the host the truth, when he saw his friends dying on behalf of a 
phantom, nor yet did Helenus; but the city was stormed in vain. Perhaps 
thou wilt say, 'twas not heaven's will that they should do so. Then why 
do we employ these prophets? Better were it to sacrifice to the gods, and 
crave a blessing, leaving prophecy alone; for this was but devised as a 
bait to catch livelihood, and no man grows rich by divination if he is 
idle. No! sound judgment and discernment are the best of seers.
lines.speaker: MESSENGER

lines.value:
My views about seers agree exactly with this old man's: whoso 
hath the gods upon his side will have the best seer in his house.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Good! so far all is well. But how camest thou, poor husband, 
safe from Troy? though 'tis no gain to know, yet friends feel a longing 
to learn all that their friends have suffered.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
That one short sentence of thine contains a host of questions. 
Why should I tell thee of our losses in the Aegean, or of the beacon Nauplius 
lighted on Euboea? or of my visits to Crete and the cities of Libya, or 
of the peaks of Perseus? For I should never satisfy thee with the tale, 
and by telling thee should add to my own pain, though I suffered enough 
at the time; and so would my grief be doubled.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Thy answer shows more wisdom than my question. Omit the rest, 
and tell me only this; how long wert thou a weary wanderer o'er the wide 
sea's face?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Seven long years did I see come and go, besides those ten in 
Troy.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Alas, poor sufferer! 'twas a weary while. And thou hast thence 
escaped only to bleed here.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: How so? what wilt thou tell? Ah wife, thou hast ruined me.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Escape and fly with all thy speed from this land. Thou wilt 
be slain by him whose house this is.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: What have I done to merit such a fate?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Thou hast arrived unexpectedly to thwart my marriage.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: What! is some man bent on wedding my wife?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Aye, and on heaping those insults on me, which I have hitherto 
endured.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Is he some private prince, or a ruler of this land?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: The son of Proteus, king of the country.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: This was that dark saying I heard the servant tell.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: At which of the barbarian's gates wert thou standing?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Here, whence like a beggar I was like to be driven.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Surely thou wert not begging food? Ah, woe is me!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: That was what I was doing, though I had not the name of beggar.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Of course thou knowest, then, all about my marriage.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: I do. But whether thou hast escaped thy lover, I know not.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Be well assured I have kept my body chaste.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: How wilt thou convince me of this? If true, thy words are sweet.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Dost see the wretched station I have kept at this tomb?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
I see, alas! a bed of straw; but what hast thou to do with 
it?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: There I crave escape from this marriage as a suppliant.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: For want of an altar, or because it is the barbarians' way?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: This was as good a protection to me as the gods' temples.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: May I not then even bear thee homeward on my ship?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: The sword far sooner than thy wife's embrace is waiting thee.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: So should I be of all men the most miserable.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Put shame aside, and fly from this land.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Leaving thee behind? 'twas for thy sake I sacked Troy.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Better so, than that our union should cause thy death.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Oh! these are coward words, unworthy of those days at Troy!
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Thou canst not slay the prince, thy possible intent.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Hath he, then, a body which steel cannot wound?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Thou shalt hear. But to attempt impossibilities is no mark 
of wisdom.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Am I to let them bind my hands, and say nothing?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Thou art in a dilemma; some scheme must be devised.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: I had liefer die in action than sitting still.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: There is one hope, and only one, of our safety.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Will gold, or daring deeds, or winning words procure it?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: We are safe if the prince learn not of thy coming.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
ary one tell him it is I? He certainly will not know who I 
am.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: He hath within his palace an ally equal to the gods.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Some voice divine within the secret chambers of his house?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: No; his sister; Theonoe men call her.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Her name hath a prophetic sound; tell me what she doth.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
She knoweth everything, and she will tell her brother thou 
art come.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Then must we die; for I cannot escape her ken.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Perchance we might by suppliant prayers win her over.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: To what end? To what vain hope art thou leading me?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: That she should not tell her brother thou art here.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Suppose we persuade her, can we get away?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Easily, if she connive thereat; without her knowledge, no,
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Be that thy task; women deal best with women.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: I will not fail, be sure, to clasp her knees.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Come, then; only, suppose she reject our proposals?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Thou wilt be slain, and I, alas! wedded by force.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: Thou wilt betray me; that "force" of thine is but an excuse.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Nay, by thy life I swear a sacred oath.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
What meanest thou? dost swear to die and never to another husband 
yield?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: Yes, by the self-same sword; I will fall by thy side.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: On these conditions touch my right hand.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
I do so, swearing I will quit the light of day if thou art 
slain.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value: I, too, will end my life if I lose thee.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value: How shall we die so as to gain fame?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
I will slay thee and then myself upon the summit of the tomb. 
But first will I in doughty fight contest another's claim to thee; and 
let who will draw nigh! for I will not sully the lustre of my Trojan fame, 
nor will I, on my return to Hellas, incur a storm of taunts, as one who 
robbed Thetis of Achilles; saw Ajax, son of Telamon, fall a weltering corpse; 
and the sort of Neleus of his child bereft; shall I then flinch myself 
from death for my own wife? No, no! For if the gods are wise, o'er a brave 
man by his foes laid low they lightly sprinkle the earth that is his tomb, 
while cowards 'they cast forth on barren rocky soil.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Grant, heaven, that the race of Tantalus may at last be blest, 
and pass from sorrow unto joy!
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Ah, woe is me! Yea, all my lot is woe; O Menelaus, we are utterly 
undone! Behold! from forth the house comes Theonoe, the prophetess, The 
palace echoes as the bolts are unfastened; fly! yet what use to fly? For 
whether absent or present she knows of thy arrival here. Ah me! how lost 
am I! Saved from Troy and from a barbarian land, thou hast come only to 
fall a prey to barbarian swords.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
THEONOE enters, attended by hand-maidens carrying 
torches.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Lead on, bearing before me blazing brands, and, as sacred rites 
ordain, purge with incense every cranny of the air, that I may breathe 
heaven's breath free from taint; meanwhile do thou, in case the tread of 
unclean feet have soiled the path, wave the cleansing flame above it, and 
brandish the torch in front, that I may pass upon my way. And when to heaven 
ye have paid the customs I exact, bear back into the house the brand from 
off the hearth. What of my prophecy, Helen? how stands it now? Thou hast 
seen thy husband Menelaus arrive without disguise, reft of his ships, and 
of thy counterfeit. Ah, hapless man! what troubles hast thou escaped, and 
art come hither, and yet knowest not whether thou art to return or to abide 
here; for there is strife in heaven, and Zeus this very day will sit in 
solemn conclave on thee. Hera, who erst was thy bitter foe, is now grown 
kind, and is willing to bring thee and thy wife safe home, that Hellas 
may learn that the marriage of Paris was all a sham, assigned to him by 
Cypris; but Cypris fain would mar thy homeward course, that she may not 
be convicted, or proved to have bought the palm of beauty at the price 
of Helen in a futile marriage. Now the decision rests with me, whether 
to ruin thee, as Cypris wishes, by telling my brother of thy presence bere, 
or to save thy life by taking Hera's side, concealing thy coming from my 
brother, for his orders are that I should tell him, whensoe'er thou shouldst 
reach these shores. Ho! one of you, go show my brother this man is here, 
that I may secure my safety.
lines.speaker: THEONOE

lines.value:
Maiden, at thy knees I fall a suppliant, and seat myself in 
this sad posture on behalf of myself and him, whom I am in danger of seeing 
slain, after I have so hardly found him. Oh! tell not thy brother that 
my husband is returned to these loving arms; save us, I beseech thee; never 
for thy brother's sake sacrifice thy character for uprightness, by evil 
and unjust means bidding for his favour. For the deity hates violence, 
and biddeth all men get lawful gains without plundering others. Wealth 
unjustly gotten, though it bring some power, is to be eschewed. The breath 
of heaven and the earth are man's common heritage, wherein to store his 
home, without taking the goods of others, or wresting them away by force. 
Me did Hermes at a critical time, to my sorrow, intrust to thy father's 
safe keeping for this my lord, who now is here and wishes to reclaim me. 
But how can he recover me if he be slain? How could thy sire restore the 
living to the dead? Oh! consider ere that the will of heaven and thy father's 
too; would the deity or would thy dead sire restore their neighbour's goods, 
or would they forbear? restore them, I feel sure. It is not, therefore, 
right that thou shouldst more esteem thy wanton brother than thy righteous 
father. Yet if thou, prophetess as thou art and believer in divine providence, 
shalt pervert the just intention of thy father and gratify thy unrighteous 
brother, 'tis shameful thou shouldst have full knowledge of the heavenly 
will, both what is and what is not, and yet be ignorant of justice. Oh! 
save my wretched life from the troubles which beset it, granting this as 
an accession to our good fortune; for every living soul loathes Helen, 
seeing that there is gone a rumour throughout Hellas that I was false unto 
my lord, and took up my abode in Phrygia's sumptuous halls. Now, if I come 
to Hellas, and set foot once more in Sparta, they will hear and see how 
they were ruined by the wiles of goddesses, while was no traitress to my 
friends after all; and so will they restore to me my virtuous name again, 
and I shall give my daughter in marriage, whom no man now will wed; and, 
leaving this vagrant life in Egypt, shall enjoy the treasures in my home. 
Had Menelaus met his doom at some funeral pyre, with tears should I be 
cherishing his memory in a far-off land, but must lose him now when he 
is alive and safe? Ah! maiden, I beseech thee, say not so; grant me this 
boon, I pray, and reflect thy father's justice; for this is the fairest 
ornament of children, when the child of a virtuous sire resembles its parents 
in character.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Piteous thy pleading, and a piteous object thou! But I fain 
would hear what Menelaus will say to save his life.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
I will not deign to throw myself at thy knees, or wet mine 
eyes with tears; for were I to play the coward, I should most foully blur 
my Trojan fame. And yet men say it shows a noble soul to let the tear-drop 
fall in misfortune. But that will not be the honourable course that I will 
choose in preference to bravery, if what I shall say is honourable. Art 
thou disposed to save a stranger seeking in mere justice to regain his 
wife, why then restore her and save us likewise; if not, this will not 
be the first by many a time that I have suffered, though thou wilt get 
an evil name. All that I deem worthy of me and honest, all that will touch 
thy heart most nearly, will I utter at the tomb of thy sire with regret 
for his loss. Old king beneath this tomb of stone reposing, pay back thy 
trust! I ask of thee my wife whom Zeus sent hither unto thee to keep for 
me. I know thou canst never restore her to me thyself, for thou art dead; 
but this thy daughter will never allow her father once so glorious, whom 
I invoke in his grave, to bear a tarnished name; for the decision rests 
with her now. Thee, too, great god of death, I call to my assistance, who 
hast received full many a corpse, slain by me for Helen, and art keeping 
thy wage; either restore those dead now to life again, or compel the daughter 
to show herself a worthy equal of her virtuous sire, and give me back my 
wife. But if ye will rob me of her, I will tell you that which she omitted 
in her speech. Know then, maiden, I by an oath am bound, first, to meet 
thy brother sword to sword, when he or I must die-there is no alternative. 
But if he refuse to meet me fairly front to front, and seek by famine to 
chase away us suppliants twain at this tomb, I am resolved to slay Helen, 
and then to plunge this two-edged sword through my own heart, upon the 
top of the sepulchre, that our streaming blood may trickle down the tomb; 
and our two corpses will be lying side by side upon this polished slab, 
a source of deathless grief to thee, and to thy sire reproach. Never shall 
thy brother wed Helen, nor shall any other; I will bear her hence myself, 
if not to my house, at any rate to death. And why this stern resolve? Were 
I to resort to women's ways and weep, I should be a pitiful creature, not 
a man of action. Slay me, if it seems thee good; I will not die ingloriously; 
but better yield to what I say, that thou mayst act with justice, and I 
regain my wife.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
On thee, maiden, it rests to judge between these arguments. 
Decide in such a way as to please one and all.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
My nature and my inclination lean towards piety; myself, too, 
I respect, and I will never sully my father's fair name, or gratify my 
brother at the cost of bringing myself into open dishonour. For justice 
hath her temple firmly founded in my nature, and since I have this heritage 
from Nereus I will strive to save Menelaus; wherefore, seeing it is Hera's 
will to stand thy friend, I will give my vote with her. May Cypris be favourable 
to me! though in me she hath no part, and I will try to remain a maid alway. 
As for thy reproaches against my father at this tomb; lo! I have the same 
words to utter; I should be wronging thee, did I not restore thy wife; 
for my sire, were he living, would have given her back into thy keeping, 
and thee to her. Yea, for there is recompense for these things as well 
amongst the dead as amongst all those who breathe the breath of life. The 
soul indeed of the dead lives no more, yet hath it a consciousness that 
lasts for ever, eternal as the ether into which it takes the final plunge. 
Briefly then to end the matter, I will observe strict silence on all that 
ye prayed I should, and never with my counsel will I aid my brother's wanton 
will. For I am doing him good service, though he little thinks it, if turn 
him from his godless life to holiness. Wherefore devise yourselves some 
way of escape; my lips are scaled; I will not cross your path. First with 
the goddesses begin, and of the one,-and that one Cypris,-Crave permission 
to return unto thy country; and of Hera, that her goodwill may abide in 
the same quarter, even her scheme to save thee and thy husband. And thou, 
my own dead sire, shalt never, in so far as rests with me, lose thy holy 
name to rank with evil-doers.
lines.speaker: THEONOE

lines.value: THEONOE and her attendants enter the palace.
lines.speaker: THEONOE

lines.value:
No man ever prospered by unjust practices, but in a righteous 
cause there is hope of safety.
lines.speaker: LEADER

lines.value:
Menelaus, on the maiden's side are we quite safe. Thou must 
from that point start, and by contributing thy advice, devise with me a 
scheme to save ourselves.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Hearken then; thou hast been a long while in the palace, and 
art intimate with the king's attendants.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
What dost thou mean thereby? for thou art suggesting hopes, 
as if resolved on some plan for our mutual help.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Couldst thou persuade one of those who have charge of cars 
and steeds to furnish us with a chariot?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
I might; but what escape is there for us who know nothing of 
the country and the barbarian's kingdom?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
True; 'tis impossible. Well, supposing I conceal myself in 
the palace and slay the king with this two-edged sword?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
His sister would never refrain from telling her brother that 
thou wert meditating his death.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
We have not so much as a ship to make our escape in; for the 
sea. hath swallowed the one we had.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Hear me, if haply even a woriian can utter words of wisdom. 
Dost thou consent to be dead in word, though not really so?
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
'Tis a bad omen; still, if by saying so I shall gain aught, 
I am ready to be dead in word, though not in deed.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
I, too, will mourn thee with hair cut short and dirges, as 
is women's way, before this impious wretch.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
What saving remedy doth this afford us twain? There is deception 
in thy scheme.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
I will beg the king of this country leave to bury thee in a 
cenotaph, as if thou hadst really died at sea.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Suppose he grant it; how, e'en then, are we to escape without 
a ship, after having committed me to my empty tomb?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
I will bid him give me a vessel, from which to let drop into 
the sea's embrace thy funeral offerings.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
A clever plan in truth, save in one particular; suppose he 
bid thee rear the tomb upon the strand, thy pretext comes to naught.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
But I shall say it is not the custom in Hellas to bury those 
who die at sea upon the shore.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Thou removest this obstacle too; I then will sail with thee 
and help stow the funeral garniture in the same ship.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Above all, it is necessary that thou and all thy sailors who 
escaped from the wreck should be at hand.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Be sure if once I find a ship at her moorings, they shall be 
there man for man, each with his sword.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Thou must direct everything; only let there be winds to waft 
our rails and a good ship to speed before them!
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
So shall it be; for the deities will cause my troubles to cease. 
But from whom wilt thou say thou hadst tidings of my death?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
From thee; declare thyself the one and only survivor, telling 
how thou wert sailing with the son of Atreus, and didst see him perish.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Of a truth the garments I have thrown about me, will bear out 
my tale that they were rags collected from the wreckage.
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
They come in most opportunely, but they were near being lost 
just at the wrong time. Maybe that misfortune will turn to fortune.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
Am I to enter the palace with thee, or are we to sit here at 
the tomb quietly?
lines.speaker: MENELAUS

lines.value:
Abide here; for if the king attempts to do thee any mischief, 
this tomb and thy good sword will protect thee. But I will go within and 
cut off my hair, and exchange my white robe for sable weeds, and rend my 
cheek with this hand's blood-thirsty nail. For 'tis a mighty struggle, 
and I see two possible issues; either I must die if detected in my plot, 
or else to my country shall I come and save thy soul alive. O Hera! awful 
queen, who sharest the couch of Zeus, grant some respite from their toil 
to two unhappy wretches; to thee I pray, tossing my arms upward to heaven, 
where thou hast thy home in the star-spangled firmament. Thou, too, that 
didst win the prize of beauty at the price of my marriage; O Cypris! daughter 
of Dione, destroy me not utterly. Thou hast injured me enough aforetime, 
delivering up my name, though not my person, to live amongst barbarians. 
Oh! suffer me to die, if death is thy desire, in my native land. Why art 
thou so insatiate in mischief, employing every art of love, of fraud, and 
guileful schemes, and spells that bring bloodshed on families? Wert thou 
but moderate, only that!-in all else thou art by nature man's most well, 
come deity; and I have reason so to say.
lines.speaker: HELEN

lines.value:
HELEN enters the palace and MENELAUS withdraws into the 
background.
lines.speaker: HELEN
